questions.text: A 65-year-old woman came for a routine health check-up. She has no symptoms, and on examination, she has a grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex. 2D Echo demonstrates severe Mitral regurgitation with LVEF of 50%. The left ventricle is moderately dilated with an LV end-systolic dimension (LVESD) of 42 mm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Serial clinical and echocardiographic evaluations: While monitoring is important, it is not the most appropriate next step in this case of severe MR with LV dilatation. Delaying surgery can lead to irreversible LV damage and worsening of symptoms.
  • • Option A. Serial clinical and echocardiographic evaluations:
  • • Option C. Surgical mitral valve replacement: Replacement is considered if repair is not feasible or if the mitral valve is severely damaged. However, repair is the preferred option whenever possible.
  • • Option C. Surgical mitral valve replacement:
  • • Option D. Transcatheter mitral valve repair: This is a less invasive option but is currently recommended for patients who are high-risk surgical candidates. This patient is asymptomatic and otherwise healthy, making her a good candidate for surgical repair.
  • • Option D. Transcatheter mitral valve repair:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indications for surgical mitral valve repair in asymptomatic patients include severe primary MR and LV dilatation (ESD ≥ 40mm and/or EF ≤ 60%).

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with recurrent chest pain and dyspnea. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Physical exam reveals elevated JVP, crackles, and a soft early systolic murmur with an S3 gallop. ECG is shown. Chest X-ray shows pulmonary congestion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Aortic stenosis: While this can cause heart failure, it would present with a harsh systolic murmur radiating to the carotids, not a soft early systolic murmur.
  • • Option A. Aortic stenosis:
  • • Option B. Cardiac tamponade: This can cause elevated JVP and distant heart sounds, but it would not typically present with a new murmur or ECG changes of MI.
  • • Option B. Cardiac tamponade:
  • • Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: This would cause a holosystolic murmur that increases with inspiration, not the early systolic murmur described in this case.
  • • Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute MR usually occurs in association with inferior MI and it is due to rupture of posteromedial papillary muscle.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with a history of connective tissue disease presents with acute shortness of breath and pulmonary edema. Examination reveals severe aortic regurgitation due to a right coronary cusp avulsion. She is in cardiogenic shock. What intervention is most likely to maintain end-organ perfusion until surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: Esmolol continuous IV infusion titrated to a heart rate of 60–70 beats/min

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Esmolol (beta-blocker) continuous IV infusion titrated to a heart rate of 60–70 beats/min: Slowing the heart rate increases diastolic time, worsening regurgitation.
  • • Option A. Esmolol (beta-blocker) continuous IV infusion titrated to a heart rate of 60–70 beats/min:
  • • Option B. Intra-aortic balloon pump: Contraindicated in severe aortic regurgitation, as it inflates during diastole, further increasing regurgitation.
  • • Option B. Intra-aortic balloon pump:
  • • Option D. IV norepinephrine : IV norepinephrine and E. Vasopressin: These are vasopressors that increase afterload, which would worsen aortic regurgitation.
  • • Option D.
  • • IV norepinephrine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acute severe aortic regurgitation with cardiogenic shock, IV nitroprusside can be used as a bridge to surgery by reducing afterload and improving forward flow.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presented with fatigue. Cardiac catheterization is done and it is demonstrated below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Aortic stenosis : This would show a pressure gradient between the left ventricle and the aorta during systole.
  • • Option B. Aortic stenosis
  • • Option C. Mitral regurgitation : This would show a high-pressure V wave in the left atrial pressure tracing during systole, due to blood regurgitating back into the left atrium.
  • • Option C. Mitral regurgitation
  • • Option D. Aortic regurgitation : This would show an elevated left ventricular diastolic pressure and a rapid decline in aortic pressure during diastole.
  • • Option D. Aortic regurgitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ LA-LV gradient during diastole is characteristic of mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with chest pain. Cardiac catheterization is done and it is demonstrated below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Mitral stenosis : This would show a pressure gradient between the left atrium and left ventricle during diastole.
  • • Option A. Mitral stenosis
  • • Option C. Mitral regurgitation : This would show a high-pressure V wave in the left atrial pressure tracing during systole, due to blood regurgitating back into the left atrium.
  • • Option C. Mitral regurgitation
  • • Option D. Aortic regurgitation : This would show an elevated left ventricular diastolic pressure and a rapid decline in aortic pressure during diastole.
  • • Option D. Aortic regurgitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The pressure gradient between the LV and the aorta during systole is hallmark of LVOT obstruction (like aortic stenosis).

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with recent post-CABG (coronary artery bypass graft) status presents with chest pain. On arrival, his blood pressure is 60/30 mmHg with a heart rate of 30/min. The ECG shows a narrow complex arrhythmia. The patient has already received three boluses of IV atropine. While awaiting transcutaneous pacing, which of the following is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Another bolus of atropine: As per ACLS guidelines, a maximum of three boluses of atropine are recommended for symptomatic bradycardia. Further doses are unlikely to be effective.
  • • Option A. Another bolus of atropine:
  • • Option B. IV Norepinephrine: While norepinephrine is a potent vasopressor, it can also worsen bradycardia due to its reflex bradycardia effect (baroreceptor response).
  • • Option B. IV Norepinephrine:
  • • Opion D. IV Dobutamine: Dobutamine primarily acts on beta-1 receptors, increasing heart rate and contractility, but it can also cause vasodilation (beta-2 effects), potentially worsening hypotension.
  • • Opion D. IV Dobutamine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Chronotropic drugs like dopamine can be tried while awaiting pacing in symptomatic bradycardia with hypotension, especially when atropine has been ineffective.

questions.text: Which of the following non-invasive tests has the best accuracy in detecting coronary stenosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. CMR perfusion have high sensitivity, but their specificity is not as high as Coronary CTA, meaning they might produce more false-positive results.
  • • Option A. CMR perfusion
  • • Option D. Exercise echocardiography and Option C. SPECT MPI have lower sensitivity and specificity than Coronary CTA, indicating a higher chance of both false negatives and false positives.
  • • Option D. Exercise echocardiography
  • • Option
  • • C. SPECT MPI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Coronary CTA is a highly accurate non-invasive test for detecting coronary stenosis due to its excellent sensitivity and specificity. It is a valuable tool for diagnosing and evaluating CAD.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man with bacterial pneumonia experiences a sudden lightheadedness. His BP is stable, and the rhythm strip is shown. Which of the following is most likely to lead to sustained improvement in heart rate?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Adenosine 6 mg IV : Primarily used for supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and may not be effective in FAT.
  • • Option A. Adenosine 6 mg IV
  • • Option B. Carotid body massage : A vagal maneuver that may temporarily slow the heart rate but is not a definitive treatment.
  • • Option B. Carotid body massage
  • • Option D. Valsalva maneuver : A vagal maneuver that may temporarily slow the heart rate but is not a definitive treatment.
  • • Option D. Valsalva maneuver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Focal atrial tachycardia is not dependent on the AV node and beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine CCBs are the preferred treatment options for rate control.

questions.text: You are called to the ER for a young patient in cardiac arrest during exercise. ECG showed bidirectional VT and it was cardioverted immediately. ECG post-cardioversion is normal. 2D Echo and cardiac MRI are also normal. Mutations in which protein are responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Desmosomal proteins: Mutations in desmosomal proteins cause arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC), which is a structural heart disease.
  • • Option B. Desmosomal proteins:
  • • Option C. Potassium channel: Mutations in potassium channels can cause long QT syndrome. In this case resting ECG would have showed long QTc.
  • • Option C. Potassium channel:
  • • Option D. Sarcomere proteins: Mutations in sarcomere proteins cause hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which would have resulted in structural heart disease.
  • • Option D. Sarcomere proteins:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize bidirectional VT as a hallmark of CPVT, an inherited arrhythmia syndrome caused by mutations in the cardiac ryanodine receptor (RyR2).

questions.text: You are seeing a 75-year-old man admitted for non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction. He has a history of CAD and takes daily aspirin. He's had multiple angina episodes in the past few days, has ST-segment depression on ECG, and elevated troponin. Which of the following details does NOT confer increased risk of poor outcomes?

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above confer increased risk.

questions.correct_answer: D. All of the above confer increased risk.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Two anginal episode in 24 hours : High risk indicating loss of ischemic preconditioning and an active/ongoing ischemia.
  • • Option A. Two anginal episode in 24 hours
  • • Option B. Age : Advanced age is the SINGLE most important risk factor in ACS.
  • • Option B. Age
  • • Option C. Daily aspirin use : While aspirin is cardioprotective, ACS despite use of aspirin indicates high thrombus burden and hence, high risk.
  • • Option C. Daily aspirin use

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ TIMI score for NSTE-ACS is important!

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with an chest pain, nausea and diaphoresis. ECG is shown. The nearest tertiary care center is 140 minutes away. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: B
options.text: Thrombolysis and admission to a telemetry bed

options.label: C
options.text: Thrombolysis and transfer to a PCI center

options.label: D
options.text: Transfer to a tertiary care center

questions.correct_answer: C. Thrombolysis and transfer to a PCI center
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. CT angiography : Delays reperfusion therapy, which is crucial in STEMI.
  • • Option A. CT angiography
  • • Option B. Thrombolyse and admit : Does not allow for timely angiography and potential rescue PCI.
  • • Option B. Thrombolyse and admit
  • • Option D. Transfer to tertiary care center : Delays reperfusion and worsens outcomes.
  • • Option D. Transfer to tertiary care center

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ For patients with STEMI, thrombolytic therapy is recommended if symptom onset is within 12 hours and PPCI is not available within 120 minutes of FMC.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents with severe chest pain for the last 3 hours. She is diaphoretic and appears drowsy. Her BP is 80/60 mm Hg and PR is 60/min. ECG is shown below. She was started on aspirin, clopidogrel and heparin. What is the next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Atropine: Atropine may be useful for bradycardia but is unlikely to be effective in the setting of high-grade AV block. Additionally, it does not address the underlying myocardial ischemia.
  • • Option A. Atropine:
  • • Option B. Tenecteplase: While fibrinolysis with tenecteplase may be considered in some STEMI cases, it is not the first-line therapy in this case.
  • • Option B. Tenecteplase:
  • • Option C. Primary Angioplasty: Primary PCI is the preferred reperfusion strategy for STEMI, but it should be performed after stabilizing the patient's hemodynamics with temporary pacing.
  • • Option C. Primary Angioplasty:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Anterior MI related bradyarrhythmias are inherently unstable and need temporary pacing.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman presents with cardiogenic shock. ECG showed ST depressions in multiple leads and her Troponins were elevated. PCI was performed successfully but she continues to be in cardiogenic shock and she is on aspirin, prasugrel and norepinephrine. Which of the following is the most appropriate additional management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Digoxin : Weak inotrope, unlikely to be effective in cardiogenic shock.
  • • Option A. Digoxin
  • • Option C. Metoprolol : Beta-blocker, contraindicated in cardiogenic shock due to negative inotropic effects.
  • • Option C. Metoprolol
  • • Option D. Urgent cardiac transplantation : Not feasible in the acute setting.
  • • Option D. Urgent cardiac transplantation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ IABP is a mechanical circulatory support device that can temporarily improve hemodynamics in patients with cardiogenic shock after MI by reducing afterload and improving coronary perfusion.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman with a history of NSTEMI and AF underwent a successful PCI with a drug eluting stent. What is the most appropriate management of her antithrombotic therapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Aspirin plus clopidogrel: This is traditional dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) and does not address the need for anticoagulation in AF.
  • • Option A. Aspirin plus clopidogrel:
  • • Option B. Aspirin plus ticagrelor: Similar to option a, it lacks anticoagulation for AF.
  • • Option B. Aspirin plus ticagrelor:
  • • Option C. Aspirin plus rivaroxaban plus ticagrelor: Triple therapy is no longer recommended as it increases bleeding risk without significant additional benefit compared to dual therapy.
  • • Option C. Aspirin plus rivaroxaban plus ticagrelor:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Among patients with atrial fibrillation who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome, double therapy with clopidogrel or ticagrelor plus a direct oral anticoagulant is recommended over triple therapy with an oral anticoagulant, aspirin, and P2Y12 inhibitor to reduce the risk for bleeding.

questions.text: A 51-year-old male presents with chest pain, 4 days after he was diagnosed with an ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). It is severe, central chest pain with radiation to the trapezius and worse with deep inspiration. The pain woke him from sleep and has improved slightly after getting up out of bed. His Troponin levels were unchanged and ECG showed new saddle-shaped ST elevations in inferior and lateral leads. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Recurrent MI: While possible, the unchanged troponin and the specific characteristics of the chest pain make it less likely.
  • • Option A. Recurrent MI:
  • • Option C. Dressler's Syndrome: This is a post-MI syndrome occurring weeks to months after the infarction, characterized by fever, pericarditis, pleuritis, and leukocytosis. It is too early for this diagnosis.
  • • Option C. Dressler's Syndrome:
  • • Option D. Severe GERD due to aspirin: GERD can cause chest pain, but the pain is typically burning and not pleuritic. Additionally, the ECG changes are not consistent with GERD.
  • • Option D. Severe GERD due to aspirin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Early pericarditis is a common complication of STEMI that typically occurs in the first week after MI.

questions.text: An 18-year-old athlete experiences cardiac arrest during a race and is successfully resuscitated. Resting ECG is shown. Echocardiogram shows normal LV function but RV dilation and dysfunction. What is the most appropriate management before discharge?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Amiodarone: Antiarrhythmic medication, but not as effective as ICD for preventing sudden death.
  • • Option A. Amiodarone:
  • • Option B. Genetic testing: Important for diagnosis and family screening, but not the immediate priority before discharge.
  • • Option B. Genetic testing:
  • • Option D. Lisinopril: ACE inhibitor for LV dysfunction, not indicated in this case with normal LV function.
  • • Option D. Lisinopril:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with sustained ventricular arrhythmias (>30 seconds) or cardiac arrest without a reversible cause have a class 1 recommendation for secondary prevention with implantable cardioverter-defibrillator placement.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with ascites, pedal edema and elevated JVP. ECG showed low voltage complexes and echo showed increased LV wall thickness. He also has a history of carpal tunnel syndrome. What is the most appropriate test?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Exercise echocardiography: Primarily used to diagnose coronary artery disease.
  • • Option B. Exercise echocardiography:
  • • Option C. Right and left heart catheterization: Invasive and not the first-line test for infiltrative cardiomyopathy.
  • • Option C. Right and left heart catheterization:
  • • Option D. Serum α-galactosidase level: Used to diagnose Fabry disease, which usually causes Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy.
  • • Option D. Serum α-galactosidase level:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging with gadolinium is highly sensitive and specific for cardiac amyloidosis, but it does not distinguish between AL (immunoglobulin light-chain) amyloidosis and transthyretin amyloidosis.
  • ➤ In patients with cardiac magnetic resonance imaging findings consistent with cardiac amyloidosis, an abnormal 99m-technetium pyrophosphate scan would confirm transthyretin amyloidosis without the need for a biopsy.

questions.text: An 8-day postpartum woman presents with acute heart failure symptoms. Echocardiogram shows LV dilation and hypokinesis with an ejection fraction of 38%.RV is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Acute pulmonary embolism : Less likely given normal right heart function on echocardiogram.
  • • Option A. Acute pulmonary embolism
  • • Option B. Ascending aortic dissection: Usually presents with acute chest pain, and echo would show aortic abnormalities.
  • • Option
  • • B. Ascending aortic dissection:
  • • Option D. Spontaneous coronary artery dissection: Typically presents with chest pain and ECG changes indicative of ischemia.
  • • Option
  • • D. Spontaneous coronary artery dissection:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Peripartum cardiomyopathy is left ventricular systolic dysfunction with onset toward the end of pregnancy or in the months after delivery in the absence of another identifiable cause; patients often present with features of heart failure.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy (EF 20%) is on maximally tolerated heart failure medications and experiencing significant functional decline. He wishes to pursue care that will restore functionality. What is the most appropriate long-term treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Digoxin: Although it can reduce hospitalizations, it does not improve survival or functional capacity.
  • • Option A. Digoxin:
  • • Option C. LVAD placement: LVADs are a bridge to transplantation or destination therapy for those who are not transplant candidates. This patient may be eligible for transplant.
  • • Option C. LVAD placement:
  • • Option D. Tolvaptan: Used for hyponatremia, but not a primary treatment for advanced heart failure.
  • • Option D. Tolvaptan:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with persistent severe heart failure symptoms despite maximal medical therapy are candidates for advanced treatment; acceptable candidates for cardiac transplantation are generally younger than 65 to 70 years with no medical contraindications and have good social support and adherence.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a history of HFrEF and AF, presents for follow-up with stable NYHA class III symptoms. He is currently on losartan, carvedilol, empagliflozin, furosemide, and apixaban. He has a history of ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema and spironolactone-induced gynecomastia. Which medication is the most appropriate addition to his current regimen?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Ivabradine: Not indicated in patients with atrial fibrillation.
  • • Option
  • • B. Ivabradine:
  • • Option C. Switch carvedilol to metoprolol succinate: Not necessary, as there is no evidence of benefit in switching between beta-blockers in this scenario.
  • • Option
  • • C. Switch carvedilol to metoprolol succinate:
  • • benefit in switching between beta-blockers in this scenario.
  • • Option D. Switch losartan to valsartan-sacubitril: Contraindicated due to the history of ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema.
  • • Option
  • • D. Switch losartan to valsartan-sacubitril:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aldosterone antagonist therapy (spironolactone, eplerenone) is indicated in all patients with symptomatic heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and normal kidney function to improve survival.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with paroxysmal AF and HFrEF (EF 45%) has recurrent hospitalizations due to acute heart failure. She is currently on apixaban, metoprolol, furosemide, and telmisartan. What is the most appropriate treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Atrioventricular (AV) node ablation with permanent pacemaker implantation

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. AV node ablation: Considered only if rate and rhythm control fails to control tachycardia.
  • • Option A. AV node ablation:
  • • Option B. ICD: Indicated for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death in certain patients, but not the primary treatment for this patient.
  • • Option B. ICD:
  • • Option C. LAAO: Used for stroke prevention in patients who have C/I for anticoagulation.
  • • Option C. LAAO:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aggressive efforts to achieve rhythm control in patients with atrial fibrillation and concomitant heart failure decrease morbidity and mortality.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for a 1-week history of progressive exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. Vital signs are normal. Focused point-of-care cardiac ultrasonography is performed and done and as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction

questions.correct_answer: C. Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Aortic stenosis : Aortic stenosis typically presents with symptoms such as chest pain, syncope, and heart failure. However, the ultrasound findings do not suggest aortic valve pathology or significant left ventricular outflow obstruction.
  • • Option A. Aortic stenosis
  • • Option B. Cardiac tamponade : Cardiac tamponade would present with findings such as hypotension, jugular venous distension, and pulsus paradoxus. The ultrasound in tamponade typically shows a large pericardial effusion with diastolic collapse of the right atrium or right ventricle. These findings are not present in this case.
  • • Option B. Cardiac tamponade
  • • Option D. Large pericardial effusion : A large pericardial effusion would show a significant fluid accumulation around the heart on ultrasound, often leading to tamponade physiology. This is not observed in the provided ultrasound image.
  • • Option D. Large pericardial effusion
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Recognize the clinical presentation of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) and correlate it with echocardiographic findings, emphasizing the importance of identifying left ventricular systolic dysfunction in patients presenting with symptoms of heart failure.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for acute worsening of dyspnea. Chest radiograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cardiac tamponade : While cardiomegaly can be seen in cardiac tamponade, which is a condition where fluid accumulates in the sac surrounding the heart, leading to compression of the heart, diffuse alveolar infiltrates are not a feature of cardiac tamponade. Therefore, this diagnosis is unlikely based on the radiographic findings.
  • • Option A. Cardiac tamponade
  • • Option B. Eosinophilic pneumonia : Eosinophilic pneumonia is characterized by the presence of eosinophils (a type of white blood cell) in the lung tissue, which typically presents with bilateral infiltrates on a chest radiograph. However, this condition does not usually present with cardiomegaly or pleural effusion, making this option less likely given the findings on the radiograph.
  • • Option B. Eosinophilic pneumonia
  • • Option C. Lymphangioleiomyomatosis: Lymphangioleiomyomatosis is a rare lung disease that affects the lungs and lymphatic system, leading to cystic lung disease. The chest radiograph for this condition would typically show diffuse thin-walled cysts rather than cardiomegaly, alveolar infiltrates, or pleural effusion. Thus, this diagnosis is inconsistent with the radiographic findings in this patient.
  • • Option
  • • C. Lymphangioleiomyomatosis:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Pulmonary edema is characterized by cardiomegaly and bilateral perihilar alveolar infiltrates on a chest radiograph, often associated with pleural effusion and fluid in the minor fissure, especially in the context of heart failure. This is a key diagnostic feature that must be remembered.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a past medical history of coronary artery disease develops a myocardial infarction. He got treated in CCU and before he is discharged, he undergoes echocardiography, which reveals a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35% to 40%. He is asymptomatic. Repeat Echo after 3 months shows the same findings. What is this patient’s heart failure stage?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Stage A: Patients in Stage A have risk factors for HF but no structural heart disease or symptoms.
  • • Option A. Stage A:
  • • Option C. Stage C: Patients in Stage C have structural heart disease and current or prior symptoms of HF.
  • • Option C. Stage C:
  • • Option D. Stage D: Patients in Stage D have refractory HF requiring specialized interventions.
  • • Option D. Stage D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ACC/AHA staging system for heart failure, categorizes patients based on the presence or absence of structural heart disease and symptoms of heart failure.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman with a history of recurrent heart failure hospitalizations presents with ascites and edema. Her JVP was elevated and there was no change with inspiration. On examination, she has an audible low-pitched late diastolic sound with a pansystolic murmur in the left sternal border. Echo shows diastolic dysfunction with mildly increased LV wall thickness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Constrictive pericarditis: While this can also cause elevated JVP and diastolic dysfunction, it usually does not present with a pansystolic murmur or S3 gallop. Pericardial knock is more characteristic.
  • • Option A. Constrictive pericarditis:
  • • Option B. Fabry disease: This is a rare genetic disorder that can cause RCM, but it is less likely than other causes in this patient without a specific family history or other suggestive features.
  • • Option B. Fabry disease:
  • • Option C. Dilated cardiomyopathy: This presents with systolic dysfunction (reduced ejection fraction) and a dilated left ventricle, which are not seen in this case.
  • • Option C. Dilated cardiomyopathy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Restrictive cardiomyopathy presents with features of right heart failure, Kussmaul's sign, S3/S4 gallop, diastolic dysfunction, and associated findings like TR.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with acute chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw. ECG is shown. Which coronary artery is most likely occluded?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Left anterior descending (LAD) artery : Occlusion of the LAD artery typically causes ST-segment elevation in anterior leads.
  • • Option A. Left anterior descending (LAD) artery
  • • Option B. Left circumflex (LCx) artery : Occlusion of the LCx artery typically causes ST-segment elevation in lateral leads.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is newly diagnosed with idiopathic membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I. Which of the following statements regarding their prognosis is MOST accurate?

options.text: Renal function typically remains stable for at least 20 years after diagnosis.

questions.explanation:

  • • Option B. Renal function typically remains stable for at least 20 years after diagnosis: Renal function typically declines over time, with 90% of patients developing renal insufficiency within 20 years.

  • • Renal function typically remains stable for at least 20 years after diagnosis:

Approximately half of the patients progress to ESRD within 10 years, emphasizing the need for early diagnosis and management to potentially slow disease progression. While treatments like corticosteroids may be used, they do not guarantee prevention of ESRD.
